title: Rhoicissus tomentosa
text:
Rhoicissus tomentosa (or the Cape grape) is a vigorous, evergreen vine that is indigenous to the <a href="Afromontane">afro-montane forests</a> of <a href="southern%20Africa">southern Africa</a>. It is increasingly popular as an ornamental creeper in gardens, and it has a wide range of uses in traditional medicine.
Appearance.
A lush, dense, attractive creeper that naturally reaches up to the <a href="forest">forest</a> canopy and covers the tree-tops with its foliage. New velvety shoots grow upwards, reaching out with their <a href="tendril">tendril</a>s, while old stems or <a href="liana">liana</a>s hang like rope from the canopy.
The large, simple, roughly circular leaves are deep green above and soft and velvety below. In fact, they resemble the 3-lobed leaves of their Eurasian relative, the Grapevine ("<a href="Vitis%20vinifera">Vitis vinifera</a>"), with slightly serrated, wavy margins. The leaves start off as maroon or copper-coloured with thick velvety fur ("tomentosa" = "velvety"), they turn a dark rich green as they mature, and finally before they fall they become crimson.<br>
The creeper produces clumps of furry flower-buds that open into small <a href="flower">flower</a>s in summer. These are followed by bunches of dark purple, edible, <a href="grape">grape</a>-like <a href="berries">berries</a>. The berries make a good jam.
Distribution.
The Cape grape can be found throughout the wetter regions of southern Africa, from the forests on the eastern slopes of <a href="Table%20Mountain">Table Mountain</a>, eastwards throughout the coastal afro-temperate forests of <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a> (<a href="Cape%20Provinces">Cape Provinces</a>, <a href="KwaZulu-Natal">KwaZulu-Natal</a>, <a href="Northern%20Provinces">Northern Provinces</a>) and then on to <a href="Zimbabwe">Zimbabwe</a> and <a href="Malawi">Malawi</a>.
Growing "Rhoicissus tomentosa".
A very attractive and easy-to-grow creeper for gardening. Its even, multi-coloured, evergreen foliage is particularly attractive and ornamental, and it makes a good local alternative to <a href="ivy">ivy</a> for African gardens. It can also be grown in the shade (and even indoors) as well as in the open sun.
It can be used as a groundcover in shady areas; it can be planted to grow up walls like ivy (although it requires a trellis of some sort for its tendrils to hold onto); it readily climbs up and over a fence to form a screen or hedge; and it can even be used to make wire-basket topiaries.<br>
The Cape Grape can easily be grown from seed, although cuttings can also be rooted.
